captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

ZACK KLAPMAN: Where are
we going again?

MIKE MUSTO: We're going to go
down to JCG Restorations.
They're down in Oxnard.

ZACK KLAPMAN: Why are
we going there?
MIKE MUSTO: They built--

remember when we filmed Mary's
car, Jimi Day's car?
Chris Gonzalez is the owner.

He had a lot, a lot of work
into both of these cars.

And actually, Jimi
told me about it.

I mean, he's like, dude,
you have to go down
and see these things.

Anyway, he's got this crazy
Camaro down there called Blu

Balz, and I suppose
it's like--
ZACK KLAPMAN: Of course.
MIKE MUSTO: 500, I think--

I think it's 540-plus horsepower
at the rear wheels.

But Jimi was saying that the
amount of custom work that

this car has on it is
simply outstanding.

I mean, and it's not just so
much the custom work, but the

level of detail is something
that he hasn't really seen.
ZACK KLAPMAN: All right.
That's good.

Hopefully, because it's
not every day you
MIKE MUSTO: Well, I know.

I mean, it's-- that
guy's got the same
hubcaps as a battle wagon.
[BEEP]
MIKE MUSTO: JCG Restorations.
All right.

ZACK KLAPMAN: That's
a lot of signage.

MIKE MUSTO: Let's
see what's up.
Want to knock?
ZACK KLAPMAN: I want coffee.

MIKE MUSTO: They don't
have coffee.

It's a machine shop,
like you said.

Let's see what this
thing's all about.

ZACK KLAPMAN: Door says
pull, genius.
[THEME MUSIC]

MIKE MUSTO: Tucked away in a
small industrial park in

Oxnard, California, sits JCG
Restorations and Customs, a

moderately sized performance
and fabrication facility

that's been silently producing
some of the baddest

pro-touring cars that
we've ever seen.

Unfortunately, due to Mother
Nature not cooperating, our

time in the Blu Balz Camaro
was extremely limited.

But this actually turned out to
be a silver lining, as shop

owner Chris Gonzalez was now
able to take us through the

ins and outs of what makes
this particular
1968 Camaro so special.

You obviously know Jimi Day,
Mary Pozzi very well.
CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yes, I do.

MIKE MUSTO: Jimi actually
recommended that we call you,

because he was saying that
you guys have just an
eclectic mix of cars.

I mean, one of them is
the Bonneville that's
sitting behind us.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yeah, that '65
Bonneville, which belongs to a

good friend of mine,
Dennis Winstead.

We were trying to have that one
done for you so you can do

that one, but unfortunately,
time was against us.

So I submitted the pictures of
this one, and I know that

Camaros are not something
that--

they're just over
and over and--

MIKE MUSTO: They're over and
over, but just so everybody

realizes, this is not like
your average Camaro.
And there are so many--

the amount of subtle touches on
this car that put it above

and beyond anything that
we've ever seen--
CHRIS GONZALEZ: Thank you.

MIKE MUSTO: --is
amazing to me.

So, give us the start
to finish.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: This '68 Camaro
was bought by Karl

Dunn, and Karl had been
following some of the work

that we had been doing
on Lateral-g by
doing wide-body Camaros.

He had this car that was being
built, and the timeline and

the timeframe was not
there for him.

And he wanted a car, like, right
now, so he bought this
'68 Camaro.

Had it brought out my way,
and we start talking.

I said, Karl, I got this
real cool idea.

I got these ideas and these
concepts in my head of this
Camaro that I want to build.

And I'm a big Trans-Am
theme kind of guy.

I like Trans-Am themed
'68, '69 Camaros.
MIKE MUSTO: Yeah.

Like the old Penske cars
and stuff like that?
CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yeah.

I'm a big fan of Trans-Am
racing.

I used to restore Camaros
before I started doing

customs, so I always had
this vision of a
Penske-Donohue '68 Camaro.
MIKE MUSTO: OK.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: And I started
off with that.

So we got going on the
rendering, and the rendering
kept on going and going.

I said, well, how about flush
mounted taillights, and how

about no signal lights
in the grill.

How about you widen it
up, and let's do 1970
Mustang mirrors on it.
Let's see what it looks like.
Let's try something different.
Clean it up.

All blue-black, no chrome, no
trim-- you know, just kind of

make it like a stealth looking
kind of Camaro.

MIKE MUSTO: Tell us about the
rear fenders, because you go

in, and if you look at this
next to a stock Camaro, a

stock Camaro sits like this, and
this car sits like this.
CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yeah.

MIKE MUSTO: So how wide
are those back there?

CHRIS GONZALEZ: The ones in the
back-- we stretched the

car out 2 inches in the
back and an inch and
a half in the front.

The 2-inch stretch in the back
is basically cutting the

fender up on top, and then
what we did was we add
material to the top.

And then what we do is we give
it a bow, a very subtle bow,
just enough to bring it out.

But at the same time,
it kind of gives
it like a wing effect.

It kind of makes it gradually
go in there.

So what we tried to do is all
these changes that we did to
the car, they're subtle.

I don't want them in your face,
but I want you to sit

there and look at it
and say, there's
something going on here.
[CAR ENGINE]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: As we all know,
weather can sometimes be a

bitch as was the case during
our filming at JCG.

And then combine that with the
fact that our test car pumps

out over 600 horsepower and has
a 345-series rear tire,

and, well, you can see why we
decided to err on the side of
caution during this shoot.

Rest assured though, you will
be seeing this car again, I
promise, and soon.
[CAR ENGINE REVS]

CHRIS GONZALEZ: The car, again,
stretched 2 inches in

the back, inch and a
half in the front.
345 30-19s in the back--
Forgeline wheels.
I'm a big Forgeline guy.

I love to use Forgeline
wheels.

MIKE MUSTO: Is it the quality
of the product?
CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yes.
Yeah.
I mean, put the tires on.

I don't have to balance
them, and I can do a
buck 20, a buck 30.
What else can you ask for?
MIKE MUSTO: Right.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: Recently, the
most recent change that we

made to the car is putting
305 30-19s on the front.

MIKE MUSTO: That's a lot of
meat to just stuff under a
front and make it work.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yeah,
it was a challenge.

We had a few things
we had to change.

There was a few little tweaks
and modifications that I had
to make to make that work.

MIKE MUSTO: Because, I
mean, we drove it.

We took it for a little
ride, and there was--
that was the biggest thing.

I mean, so many of these care
that are put together, you

hear kind of squeaks
and rattles.

If you hit an imperfection in
the pavement, you'll feel that
kind of jarring.

And there wasn't anything
with this car.

And that's one of the reasons
that I'm like-- and I didn't

realize that they were that big,
but that's a lot of meat.
CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yeah.
There's a lot of tire.
There's a lot of meat.
There's a lot of shock.

There's a lot of spring
behind this car.

I mean, when I tell people
how much spring--

what the spring rate I have in
this car, it's not typical for
what everybody else does.

I've been very fortunate that
I've had some of the best

autocrossers in the West Coast
behind the scene--

MIKE MUSTO: That actually
helped you test
this car and develop--
CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yeah.

There's a few guys that have
actually helped out a lot, and

there's one key guy, Casey,
that's part of my crew that's
come in and--

he just has dialed in this car
and just got it to where we
need it to be right now.

MIKE MUSTO: I mean, it's so hard
to express the level of

craftsmanship in this car, and
there's so many things that

most people are going to
walk by and they're
never going to notice.

So like, the grill, for
instance, is a custom piece
that's made out of billet.

So many of the things
that are subtle.

I mean, you'll look at this
car, and from the custom

billet gauge cluster that's
laid out as something that

looks like Chevy should have
done, but never got around to

or simply didn't have the talent
to do, to the center

console, which is something that
should be found in every

Porsche out there, because not
only does it look the way it

should, but it's unbelievably
functional, to the seats.

There's a big synergy
with this.

It really is the complete
package, and not a lot of
people can do that.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: I would call
Karl, and I'll say, look, I
got this idea.
This is what I'm thinking.
He wouldn't ask me a price.

He would just say, OK, give me
two options, three options.

I would get him two
or three options.
MIKE MUSTO: Right.
OK.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: Within 10 or 15
minutes, we had a decision.
MIKE MUSTO: Right.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: Hang up,
and we just go--

MIKE MUSTO: And you
just went with it.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: And
went with it.

So in that aspect of it,
I got very lucky.

Karl gave me a lot of
free range to do a
lot of my own things.
The engine bay is all me.

MIKE MUSTO: So what do you
have in this thing,
power-wise?

CHRIS GONZALEZ: This thing's an
LS-7 that was built for me
by QMP Racing.

I called Mike at QMP Racing one
day, and I said, Mike, I

need you to rebuild
an LS-7 for me.

I said, this is what
I need it to do.

I need to maintain torque
and power band from

He says, all right, I'll see
what I can do for you.

So I took the motor
over to him.
He tore it apart.

He balanced it-- well, we didn't
really balance it.

He just blueprinted the engine,
because we still

maintained the stock crank and
the stock titanium rods.

MIKE MUSTO: Now, did you talk
to him about that, and said,

OK, well this car is purpose
built as an autocrosser, or

we're going to use it-- we
need to do it for an

autocross, a stop-- like did
you design this car around
like the Optima challenge?

Pretty much, like, we need
it to do XYZ event.

We need a motor that's going to
provide us the power, the

torque, and the reliability
to do XYZ event.
Can you build it?
CHRIS GONZALEZ: Yes.
MIKE MUSTO: There you go.
OK.
OK.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: That has been
mine and Karl's vision from
the get go.
This is what Karl wanted.

MIKE MUSTO: So this car was
built to kick the [BEEP]
out of every other car there.
You could just say yes or no.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: How
about I say that--

MIKE MUSTO: I'm putting
you on the spot.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: --it's designed
to give everybody a
run for their money.

MIKE MUSTO: Do you look
at this car as--

as the cars you've built thus
far, is this one up here?
CHRIS GONZALEZ: This is it.

This is so far the highest level
car that I've built so
far with no bars.

In other words, I was allowed to
do a lot of the things that

I wanted to do with
this thing.
MIKE MUSTO: Thanks, Chris.
CHRIS GONZALEZ: You got it.
MIKE MUSTO: So good.

So, you guys obviously know
that we're not shop guys.

We generally don't showcase,
and we generally don't film

shops, and there's a
reason for that.

We try to bring you cars that
are kind of home-brewed and

that there's great stories
behind them.

And there's no exception
with this car.

It does have a great
story behind it.

But the thing is, when we get
people that we've already

interviewed and cars that we've
already driven saying

the same thing about one
guy and one shop,
it piques our interest.

The best part about that
Bonneville not being done is

that we were introduced
to this car.

Now, yes, the name is Blu Balz,
and yes, that's what

it's leaving with us today, but
it doesn't mean we're not

going to come back
to it, because--

just because Mother Nature
gave us the middle finger

today, it doesn't mean we're
not going to come back and

punch her in the eye
with this car.
Because it's too good not to.

So as always guys, thanks again
for tuning in to "Big

Muscle" on Drive, and we'll see
you soon with this car.
[ENGINE ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: Why did you want to
build something like this

as opposed to go and get like
a GT3 or a Ferrari or
something along those lines?

CHRIS GONZALEZ: Hold
on a second.
Edwin--
[SPEAKING SPANISH].
[BEEP]
Sorry about that.
Are we going to get bloopers?

MIKE MUSTO: We've got more
bloopers than we--

ZACK KLAPMAN: We always
put bloopers.

MIKE MUSTO: We always
put bloopers.
He's got a great voice though.

If he wants to come out
here and get in
front of the camera--

CHRIS GONZALEZ: I have to hold
my ratchet back right behind

us while he's trying
to do all that.
OK.
Sorry about that.
MIKE MUSTO: That's OK, man.

CHRIS GONZALEZ: All
right, go ahead.

comments.text:

factory!
I know your point, but this Camaro is not an original restauration, so why 
not putting modern technology to it. It has been modified to handle/drive 
the road like a modern car and this is why it looks this way. To me it's a 
good looking Camaro, but I like more an original one.

comments.text:

and intended to be a race winning performance machine, not an impotent 
weakling.  You wouldn't put 14" Polyglas on a new Camaro.
comments.author: ralphinator2

comments.text:
nothing wrong with improving the car, but it has to be sympathetic and not 
change the character of the vehicle ie fitting disc brakes or radial 
tyres..it's supposed to be a classic american muscle car, not something 
from fast and furious. you wouldnt fit side pipes on a bugatti 35B would 
you?
comments.author: funkyrimpler

comments.text:

comments.author: Ashton Rountree

comments.text:
+Ashton Rountree TRUST ME im not putting in my tears, sweat, blood and

comments.author: the unfriendly apple

comments.text:
If so, get on Summit. They have awesome 350 crate motors on there for 
honestly not all that much money. If you're aiming for over 300HP make sure 
the thing stops and handles good too. You can find some OE replacement 
calipers on there that are really good and while you're at it replace all 
the suspension. New struts and shocks, strut mounts, tie rod ends, center 
link, ball joints, sway bar bushings, sway bar links…the whole deal. I have 
an '87 IROC, and yea these third gens handled great right off the factory 
line but 20+ years later everything is pretty much shot. Good luck with the 
build, man. Just don't cut corners and keep your priorities straight. it's 
easy to get caught up in how the car looks, but if it doesn't drive, stop 
and handle well….then you'll end up with a gorgeous lawn decoration.
comments.author: Ashton Rountree

race history repeats itself with this one decades on end.. ﻿
